title: Boyd Cypert
text:
Alfred Boyd Cypert (August 8, 1889 – January 9, 1973) was a <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> player, <a href="lawyer">lawyer</a>, <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democratic Party</a> <a href="politician">politician</a> and <a href="business%20manager">business manager</a>. Cypert was born in <a href="Little%20Rock%2C%20Arkansas">Little Rock, Arkansas</a> and attended the <a href="University%20of%20Arkansas">University of Arkansas</a> where he played baseball and <a href="American%20football">football</a> for the <a href="Arkansas%20Razorbacks">Razorbacks</a>. He enrolled in <a href="Harvard%20Law%20School">Harvard Law School</a> in 1912 and graduated in 1913. In 1914, he played one game with the <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> (MLB) <a href="Cleveland%20Naps">Cleveland Naps</a>. After his baseball career was over, Cypert served as the <a href="district%20attorney">district attorney</a> in Little Rock and in 1931 ran an unsuccessful bid for <a href="Arkansas%20Attorney%20General">Arkansas Attorney General</a> against four-term <a href="incumbent">incumbent</a> <a href="Hal%20Norwood">Hal Norwood</a>. Later in his life, Cypert served as the business manager of the University of Arkansas' athletic department.
Early life and baseball career.
Alfred Boyd Cypert was born on August 8, 1889 in <a href="Little%20Rock%2C%20Arkansas">Little Rock, Arkansas</a> to Thomas and Bessie Cypert of <a href="Arkansas">Arkansas</a> and <a href="Tennessee">Tennessee</a>, respectively. In 1900, Thomas Cypert was working as a <a href="grocery%20store">grocery store</a> <a href="clerk">clerk</a> in Little Rock. By 1910, Thomas Cypert found work as a <a href="real%20estate%20agent">real estate agent</a>. Boyd Cypert had one sibling, his brother Thomas Cypert, Jr. In 1910, Boyd Cypert enrolled at the <a href="University%20of%20Arkansas">University of Arkansas</a> in <a href="Fayetteville%2C%20Arkansas">Fayetteville, Arkansas</a>.While at the University of Arkansas, he was a member of Xi Chapter of the <a href="Kappa%20Sigma%20Fraternity">Kappa Sigma Fraternity</a>. While at school, he played <a href="third%20base">third base</a> for the <a href="Arkansas%20Razorbacks%20baseball">Arkansas Razorbacks baseball</a> team. He also was the <a href="quarterback">quarterback</a> for the <a href="Arkansas%20Razorbacks%20football">Arkansas Razorbacks football</a> for three years (1910–12).
In 1912, Cypert enrolled at <a href="Harvard%20Law%20School">Harvard Law School</a> in <a href="Cambridge%2C%20Massachusetts">Cambridge, Massachusetts</a>. He graduated in 1913. Cypert signed a <a href="professional%20baseball">professional baseball</a> contract in 1913. He played his first and only professional game on June 27, 1914 as a member of the <a href="Major%20League%20Baseball">Major League Baseball</a> (MLB) <a href="Cleveland%20Naps">Cleveland Naps</a>. In that game, he <a href="strikeout">struck out</a> once in one <a href="at-bat">at-bat</a>. Defensively, Cypert played third base. During <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>, Cypert served in the <a href="United%20States%20Army">United States Army</a> and later received an <a href="honorable%20discharge">honorable discharge</a>. In 1921, Cypret was a <a href="pitcher">pitcher</a> for the Arkansas Razorbacks alumni baseball team.
Law and political career.
By 1920, Cypert worked as a <a href="general%20practice">general practice</a> <a href="lawyer">lawyer</a> in Little Rock, Arkansas. In late-January 1922, Cypert was nominated for the position of <a href="district%20attorney">district attorney</a> in Little Rock. However, it was not until 1926 when Cypert was elected Arkansas Sixth Judicial District Attorney. His constituency covered <a href="Pulaski%20County%2C%20Arkansas">Pulaski</a> and <a href="Perry%20County%2C%20Arkansas">Perry County, Arkansas</a>. His deputy district attorney was <a href="Carl%20Edward%20Bailey">Carl Edward Bailey</a>, who would later go-on to be the <a href="Governor%20of%20Arkansas">Governor of Arkansas</a>. In 1928, Cypert <a href="prosecuted">prosecuted</a> <a href="Charles%20Lee%20Smith">Charles Smith</a>, the president of <a href="Advancement%20of%20Atheism">Advancement of Atheism</a>, on <a href="blasphemy">blasphemy</a> charges after he was distributing pamphlets which read: "<a href="Evolution">Evolution</a> is true; the <a href="Bible">Bible</a> is a lie; and <a href="God">God</a> is a <a href="ghost">ghost</a>".
In November 1928, after the State of Arkansas passed a law banning the teaching of evolution, Cypert stated that he was not going to hunt down offenders, instead that he was going to enforce the law when asked to do so. In 1929, Cypert prosecuted <a href="Reece%20A.%20Claude">Reece A. Claude</a>, the state <a href="railroad">railroad</a> commissioner, on <a href="bribery">bribery</a> charges after investigating a <a href="Bill%20%28proposed%20law%29">bill</a> in the <a href="Arkansas%20Legislature">Arkansas Legislature</a> which Claude allegedly attempted to pay state officials to pass. In 1931, Cypert ran for <a href="Arkansas%20Attorney%20General">Arkansas Attorney General</a> against <a href="Hal%20Norwood">Hal Norwood</a>, who previously held the office. Cypert eventually lost the race. He was succeeded at his position of Arkansas Sixth Judicial District Attorney by Carl Edward Bailey.
Later life.
By 1930, Cypert was living in Little Rock, Arkansas with his wife, Blanch Cypert and their daughter, Belly. Boyd Cypert was hired as the University of Arkansas' <a href="business%20manager">business manager</a> in 1934. In 1936, Cypert considered running for Arkansas Attorney General again. He died on January 9, 1973 at the age of 83 in <a href="Washington%2C%20D.C.">Washington, D.C.</a>
